episode.title: St. Martin Evangelical Lutheran Church v. South Dakota

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll hear arguments next in St. Martin's Evangelical Church v. South Dakota.
Mr. Schilling, I think you may now proceed whenever you're ready.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

We suggest that the primary question before the Court is whether churches that operate elementary and secondary schools are exempt from the Federal Unemployment Tax Act, which is known as FUTA, as that Act is applied by the States.

If the Court should find that these schools are not, these churches are not exempt, then we have a second question, and that is whether coverage under FUTA would violate either or both of the religion clauses of the First Amendment.
The petitioners are St. Martin Evangelical Lutheran Church, which is separately incorporated under South Dakota law, and it operates an elementary day school.

The other petitioner, Northwestern Lutheran Academy, is owned and operated by the Wisconsin Synod, and it is a four-year preparatory school for entrance into one of the Synod colleges in preparation for either the teaching or the preaching ministry.
It should be noted that all teachers are regarded as ministers of the Wisconsin Synod.
This was found by the appeals referee in the original administrative hearing.
They have equal status with their preaching minister counterparts and voting rights on doctrinal matters in the church.
Now, neither of these schools that we're talking about are separately incorporated.
Prior to 1970 the Federal Unemployment Tax Act did not cover nonprofit or tax-exempt organizations.

In 1970, however, Congress required the states to cover nonprofit corporations and when it did this it created a Section 3309(b) which specifically exempted from coverage certain nonprofit employers or services.

Now, the first section, 3309(b)(1) has two parts, the subsection (a) which exempts those in the employ of a church, convention, or association of churches; and subsection (b) exempts those in the employ of an organization which is operated primarily for religious purposes and, which is not an issue here, which organization is operated, supervised, controlled, or principally supported by a church, convention, or association of churches.
Subsection (2) deals with their ministers and members of religious orders.
Subsection (3) exempted those in the employ of elementary and secondary schools.
The other exemptions are not pertinent to our case.
In 1976 Congress again amended FUTA effective in 1978, requiring primarily coverage of state and local employees, agricultural workers, and domestic workers.
And when Congress did this it eliminated that elementary and secondary school exclusion, and this is where the controversy begins.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: sSuppose there had never been that third exception?
Suppose there had never been that third exception?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I think that third exception was--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Do you think it is just superfluous or not?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --I think it had no effect on parochial schools.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: It did on nonparochial?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: It did on other nonprofit schools, and perhaps it had an effect on public schools.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But it was never needed to exempt the kinds of schools involved in this case?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's our position, yes, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Although that was never the view of the Service, I guess?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That was not the view of the Labor Department after repeal.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Or before.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Well, I think, before, Mr. Justice, it never had occasion to arise, and I don't think the Secretary of Labor--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Didn't they issue exemptions?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --No, you don't get an exemption, the exemption is automatic, Mr. Justice.
I mean, if--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: So you never have to--

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --You don't apply or do anything to get it.
It's there and you use it.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: --So you never knew why the tax wasn't collected from religious schools?
You didn't know which ones of the exemptions was being applied?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's correct.
Well, after this exemption, this elementary and secondary school exemption was removed; it seems that the State bases its argument on repeal of this subsection (3).
We maintain that the statute as it remains is clear, and that the statute controls, and that legislative history or intent is really not an issue.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Are you talking about the South Dakota statute?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I'm talking about the South Dakota statute, which is a mirror image of the federal statute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But if the South Dakota Supreme Court has construed the South Dakota statute, aren't we bound by that?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I don't think so, Mr. Justice, because the South Dakota statute is so closely interwoven with the federal statute, and--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: That question bothered me, in reading the briefs in this case, and the only discussion of it I found was in Footnote 2 of the Government's amicus brief which is rather short; it may be correct.
But you don't... none of the parties... don't discuss that question, whether or not this doesn't involve purely a question of state law.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --Well, I suggest, Mr. Justice, that it does not because the penalties to the states, if they don't comply, are so severe--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But the State Supreme Court seemed to be talking about the South Dakota law, didn't it?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --Mr. Justice, I think--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It sets it out on page A-3 of its opinion, and that's the one it discusses.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you suggesting that because of the interaction with the federal law and the question in the case, that that alters the usual rule that we won't reexamine a state court's interpretation of its own statutes?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

I think that the jurisdiction of course is there with the constitutional question we've raised, but I think the Court also, without the constitutional question, has jurisdiction to decide this question, because of the interrelationship between the state statute and the federal statute.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You're saying, then, it's like the Zacchini v. Scripps case we decided two or three years ago where we felt that the state court might have decided this case differently had they not been under a misapprehension as to federal law?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I think that's correct, yes; Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, suppose we ruled that the federal law didn't intend to subject religious schools to this tax?
Suppose we just ruled that?
You would still be subject to them in South Dakota, until the Legislature acted.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: We think this Court has power, Mr. Justice, to overrule and reverse the South Dakota Supreme Court--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, not as to the meaning of a South Dakota statute.
This Court lacks the power to do that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Until the Supreme Court changed its mind, the South Dakota statute would continue to mean exactly what it meant.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, unless, under cases like Zacchini or Benguet Consolidated Mines, we were to vacate and remand for reconsideration free of any misapprehension the state court might have had about the federal law question involved.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --If you did not want to get to the constitutional question, yes, Mr. Justice.
And we don't really think you have to get to the constitutional question.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, the point of it is that if your state supreme court construed the statute in reliance on an understanding of federal law that we say was erroneous, and we send it back, we couldn't change it from your state supreme court; but we could send it back to them, that's the suggestion, and let them reconsider their interpretation of the state statute in light of what we've said about the federal question.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That might be correct, Mr. Justice Brennan.
And I think we'd have to come back if they would not follow or wish--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, we might have another case.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --And we'd have another case.
Because we do have the constitutional issue.

I think that the South Dakota Supreme Court's interpretation was so heavily reliant on what the Secretary of Labor suggests and so heavily reliant on what the federal statute said, because they kept using the 3309 provisions, that I still think that that would be our position, that this Court does have jurisdiction aside from the constitutional question.

But our position under the statute, whether it be South Dakota or the federal statute, is that these churches are exempt either under subsection (a) because the services performed are in the employ of a church, convention, or association of churches.
We also think they might be exempt under subsection (b) because the services are for an organization which is operated primarily for religious purposes.
Our argument primarily is based on the statute.
I will first discuss (a).
I think under subsection (a) we have to define the simple language,
"service performed in the employ of a church. "
And I think we have to define what the word "church" means.
Now, the South Dakota appeals referee defined the word "church" very narrowly.
He said that the word "church" meant an individual house of worship, as has been interpreted to him to mean by the Secretary of Labor.
We think the appeals referee is wrong--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice White
turn.text: And the Department of Labor.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --and the Department of Labor is wrong, because a building can't employ somebody.

I think that the facts show that the school operated by St. Martin church is not separately incorporated, it's not a legal entity, the members of the church congregation control its operation; and, number three, the school is completely financed by the church.
If the tax is going to be paid, it's going to be paid by the church.
Likewise Northwestern Lutheran Academy is not separately incorporated.
Its control is by the Synod, and its principal source of support is from the Synod.
If you look at the common dictionary meaning of the word "church" it refers to a body or organization of religious believers, and that's, I think, the definition that we should use.

I think it's interesting that when Congress recodified the Internal Revenue Code in 1954, it stated that the term should be all-inclusive, and should be interpreted to include other organizations which as integral parts of the church are engaged in carrying out the church's functions, whether individually incorporated or not.
I think there are two excellent briefs by the Catholic Conference and by the Lutheran Church-Missouri Synod that trace some of the legislative history.
From time to time Congress has used these same words,
"church, convention, or association of churches. "
and of course it's our position that when Congress did this it kept the same meaning.
We think Congress intended a broad and a general meaning.
Now, when Congress recodified the Code in 1954, the words "or religious order" were also in the statute they were talking about.
And those words "or religious order" were deleted, because I think Congress thought that that would limit and confuse this broad definition that they intended.
The United States as amicus curiae implies that church schools are not exempt under this section because they're not a church.
Well, I don't think that's the issue.
I think the issue is whether these church schools, or the services performed in these church schools which are not separately incorporated, are performing services in the employ of the church.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Are you saying that they are essentially the same, substantially the same as the Sunday School classes or summer school classes held traditionally at Lutheran churches and others?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Chief Justice, I think that the school is a basic part of the church's mission.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: In other words, it's an implement of the faith of that church?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's correct, Mr. Chief Justice.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Is it governed by state rules?
Does it follow the state rules for education?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: The state rules of education?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Do they supervise those schools?
Do they enforce the attendance laws?
Does the state enforce the attendance laws?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Mr. Justice, the state heretofore has not really enforced their certification requirements, their attendance requirements.
They do submit attendance information.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, do you do that for your church school?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Yes, they do.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The Sunday School?
Do that for your Sunday School?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Not Sunday School.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Of course you don't, so they're different, aren't they?
Aren't they different?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Well, Sunday Schools are not a requirement of compulsory school attendance.
But a day school is--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, I mean, you said in answer to the Chief Justice that it was just the same as the Sunday School.
You didn't really mean that, did you?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --I meant, insofar as the inculcation of religious doctrine goes, I did.
Insofar as state requirements of education, I did not.
I think this question of state requirements and certification is one that might very well get to this Court some day.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The state has police power to require attendance at primary school, does it not?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Yes, it does.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: It could not, under the religion clauses, compel attendance at a Sunday School.
The State of South Dakota couldn't compel people to go to Sunday School, could they?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: No, they could not.
I think that would violate the Establishment Clause.
This question of certification has been before three states, these requirements.
And I understand that Ohio, Vermont, and Kentucky courts have restrained the states from enforcing their certification requirements on parochial schools.
I understand--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: You referred to the Synod, and according to your brief the membership of the Synod is the churches themselves rather than church officials, is that correct?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: In the Lutheran organization?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: The dictionary meaning includes both.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's correct, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: So the Synod is an assembly or a group of Lutheran churches, not of people?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's correct.
The membership are the churches.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Schilling, maybe I'm laboring the point, but the referee found, as I remember, that the primary purpose of the school was education rather than religious training.
Do you dispute that finding?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Yes, I do dispute that finding The referee found that religion is inculcated in everything they teach, but then he said that the primary purpose was education.
The word "primary" means fundamentally, in the first place, or of first importance.
And it's our position that the reason that churches provide a school system that's contiguous with that which the state provides is strictly to inculcate religious beliefs.
Insofar as the Wisconsin Synod goes, its constitution provides for conserving its doctrine and for extending its doctrine, and its constitution specifically provides for schools.
I Think the purpose of schools insofar as--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: These schools do perform the same educational function that public schools do insofar as the general education that is needed by a child, doesn't it?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --They do; yes, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But, certainly, logically, they wouldn't even exist if they didn't have some function beyond that.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That is correct.
Their function beyond that is to inculcate the religious doctrine into everything they teach, and I think that was recognized by this Court in the establishment cases in the early '70s.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Burger
turn.text: Well, is it any different in this situation from the schools of the Roman Catholic churches and others that we have dealt with?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I think the situation insofar as Roman Catholic schools or Baptist schools is all the same.

I think the statute that we're talking about, if we're talking about the federal statute, is so broad that no matter what the organizational structure of the church, it's covered under this exemption.
I don't think there's anything peculiar about the Wisconsin Synod.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Are these schools restricted to Lutheran children, or can other children attend?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: They're not restricted.
Primarily attendance is for those who are Lutheran.
I think they would take--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: That's not true in the Catholic parochial schools, is it?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --I can't speak for the Catholic parochial schools.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, you just a minute ago, you did say they were similar, though.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Well, I think they're pretty similar, insofar as their... similar insofar as their inculcating of religious doctrine.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And I gather from what you've just said, or said a few moments ago, that you don't think that the question of whether the church is a separate corporation is a dispositive question?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I don't, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: In this case they are not.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I don't think the fact--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: I say, in this case they are not, and you rather emphasized that in your statement of the facts.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --We emphasized the fact that they are not, because in our case, of course, we have that fact.

But I think, if you read Congress's statement, which also appears in the conferee statement when they recodified the Code, they used the term, that whether they're carrying out the function of the church, where there are separate corporations "or otherwise".
So I think under this broad definition of church, convention, or association of churches, they were all-inclusive, no matter what the organizational structure of a particular religious body is.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: So even though something were incorporated separately as a school, albeit a parochial school, that would not be a dispositive question in your submission?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I don't think that would be a dispositive question.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Why are the institutions of higher learning that are religious covered?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Why are they covered?
I think there's a difference between elementary schools and secondary schools.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, how about for purposes of the statute?
Why wouldn't an institution of higher learning that is controlled by a church, why wouldn't it fall within subsection (a) or (b)?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I think their freedom's--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because it's being, it's still part of the church?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --But I don't think their purpose in college is primarily religious, that is for most church colleges.
Some, that may be true, but I think for most church colleges--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, none of them... I mean, all of them are covered.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: --They're included.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: All of them are included.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: They're not exempt.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's right.
None of them are exempt.
And nobody goes through this routine of seeing whether they are performing a church function or not.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Insofar as colleges, that's correct.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How long has that been true?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I think, since 1970.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Were they not covered before?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: They were not covered before.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Because why?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Because they were a nonprofit corporation.
Nonprofit corporations were not included within the provisions.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And that was repealed?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Then that was repealed in 1970.
At which time they created this subsection (3).

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: How did you know that colleges were exempt under that section rather than under the church section?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: They were never exempt.
Because Congress did not provide an exemption for them unless they could come in under (1); they could come in as primarily religious.

I think Congress, when it spoke... when Congress came out in the '69-'70, when they brought these various nonprofit organizations in, specifically said in its reports that a separately incorporated organization like an orphanage or a home for the aged would not be covered.
And it specifically said that, in these reports, that institutions of higher education were meant to be covered unless they were seminaries or novitiates or something like that.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Would your argument be different if the exemption that was repealed had exempted the employees of church-related and other private schools?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I think our exemption would still come back under 3309(b)(1), either (a) or (b).

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Even though Congress had thought that it was repealing the exemption for those people?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, it seems to me that under the plain language of (1)(a) at least, to be exempt, the employment has to be of the church, or convention, or association churches, not of a separate corporation.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Under subsection (a)?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Right.
Now, (b) is something else again.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Except for Congress's definition?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, I'm talking about the statutory definition:
"in the employ of (a) a church or convention or association of churches. "
This is not a school.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: But they're in the employ of a church.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Of a church, and your clients are, you tell us.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's right.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But it would be dispositive of whether or not there were a separate corporation, wouldn't it?
And if the employment were by a school, then (1)(a) wouldn't cover it.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: It might then come under (1)(b).

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It might or might not come under (1)(b).

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's right, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: So the corporate organization is dispositive, at least with respect to (1)(a).
Isn't it?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I don't think so, because when Congress defined the words
"church, convention, or association of churches. "
it used that language, "separate corporation or otherwise" in its definition.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, I'm looking at the statute, which is what Congress enacted.
And the exemption is for somebody in the employ or a church or a convention or association of churches.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: If you'd look strictly at the statute, then it would appear that separate incorporated schools would not come under the subsection (a).
They would have to find their way into subsection (b).

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And that's what you stand on?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: He stands on both--

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I stand on both.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --But you're standing on (b)?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: We're standing primarily on (a).

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But you are--

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: And (b).

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: --Standing on (b).
That's my?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Yes, sir.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: If you can't come under (a), then you'll take (b)?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Then we'll take (b).

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Mr. Schilling, insofar as you rely on (b), and of course I understand you disagree with the referee's characterization as to "operated primarily for educational purposes", but would it not be necessary in every case involving a church-affiliated school, for the taxing authorities to make it an ad hoc decision as to whether that particular school was primarily for religious purposes or primarily for educational purposes, rather than having a general rule that would cover all schools.
I meant, all nonpublic schools; yes.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Aside from this constitutional question, that might be the answer, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: There might be a large number of individual determinations that would have to be made in order to determine the scope of (1)(b).

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's quite possible, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Then you'd have to decide what "religion" was, too.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That might be, but we might have the establishment problem.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, your problems were certainly non-existent before they repealed (3).

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's right; we had no problem.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: It fell right under (3) and now you say, you also fall under (1)(a) and (1)(b) if you can't get under (1)(a)?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: And (1)(b).
Or we have a constitutional problem.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Would you comment just on one thing that's mentioned in the opinion below.
It's the number of employees that Congress thought it was subjecting to the statute.
They used a figure that your opponents argue demonstrates they must have been intending to include the employees of parochial schools generally.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Well, with respect to those numbers, all I can say is, in a footnote in that report, there was a bigger number of 261,000, instead of the 242,000.
That referred to teachers, that 261,000.
And if we would then bring in our cafeteria workers and our bus drivers and our janitors and the other school people, that number would grow.
So I have trouble relating this 242,000 figure.

The only thing I have to go on is what happened in the Alabama v. Marshall conformity hearing where the Administrative Law Judge rejected reliance on it based on testimony that had taken place in that matter, that there was no record that Congress understood that figure and there was no supporting data with the figure, and then of course he refused to go along with it because the issues involved... what he said... were integral church functions.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Were there any hearings on this exemption?
When it was repealed, when it was revoked?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Yes, but the primary hearings were, all involved the public or the state and local employees.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: But there's nothing in the hearings, no data in the hearings as to what kind of employees, how many employees were being affected?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: Mr. Justice, never in the Congressional Record or debates does the word "church" or "church employees" appear.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Where did those figures come from, those 242 and 261?

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: The figure was 242,000 employees of private schools.
That's what the figure is.

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: That's correct, Mr. Justice.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, where did that come from?
Is there any evidence in the hearings as to where it came from?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: I don't know.
I think there was examination of people in that Alabama... I'm not familiar with the Alabama case.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: I know, but in the congressional hearings?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: No.
There was no discussion on that figure.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Nothing in the hearings, nothing in the testimony taken, none of the correspondence?

turn.speaker: edward_thomas_schilling
turn.label: Mr. Edward Thomas Schilling
turn.text: None that I found, Mr. Justice.
I would like to reserve some time.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: I'm afraid your time has expired.
Mr. Snyder.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice; may it please the Court:
Amici curiae, the States of Alabama and Nevada, submit that in order to resolve this case the Court need look no further than the plain language of 26 U.S.C. Section 3309(b)(1), Subsection (a).
The uncontradicted facts before this Court demonstrate that employees of church schools such as petitioners are
"in the employ of a church, or convention, or association of churches. "
and thus fit squarely within the statutory exemption provided by Congress.
The question that was raised earlier concerning the basis for federal jurisdiction, or this Court's jurisdiction over the statutory interpretation here, I think is answered by two factors.
Number one, a review of the South Dakota Supreme Court decision makes it clear they are relying solely on their understanding of congressional intent and the meaning of the federal statute.
They state at page A-5 of the petitioner's appendix, in the opinion there,
"the threshold issue is congressional intent. "
And I think the language of that opinion is clear, that they are relying on their understanding of the Secretary of Labor's interpretation and of the interpretation of the federal statute.

Under those circumstances, there are a number of cases from this Court that stand for the proposition that an erroneous understanding of federal law which is introduced into a state court decision is properly the subject of federal review even though the state court could choose voluntarily to read its own statute differently; where it states that it is relying on its understanding of federal law, this Court can correct such a misapprehension.
I think one of the best cases for that proposition is Standard Oil Company v. Johnson, which is cited at 316 US 481.

At page 483 the Court makes it quite clear that it will review an interpretation of the California highway tax, because the California Court interpreted that tax by reference to its understanding of federal law concerning the definition of an agency or a part of the United States Government.
We think, equally here, the State Supreme Court has interpreted the federal law, and it has interpreted it incorrectly.

In considering whether church school employees are employed by a church as required for the (b)(1)(a) exemption, it is important to bear in mind that the statute and the implementing regulations expressly define the words "employer" and "employee", and they define them so as to incorporate into the unemployment compensation law the common law rules for determining whether an employer-employee relationship exists.
They set forth such factors as the right to control and direct the individual's work, the furnishing of the place or tools of the work, and the right to discharge the individual.
In this case, as counsel for petitioners has already indicated, the church schools involved are run directly by the church or the Synod.

They have no separate corporate or legal existence, and therefore these schools are typical of the great variety of schools that are described in the stipulated record which is before this Court in Marshall v. Alabama and Nevada, No. 8922.

While those stipulations by the Secretary of Labor are not binding on the parties here, we believe they are helpful in understanding the position of the Department of Labor, which position was then adopted by the South Dakota Supreme Court in the decision that's under review.

The Secretary has stipulated as a matter of fact that in our states all of the Catholic, Lutheran, and fundamental Baptist church schools have no legal existence separate from their respective churches.
In those schools church officials such as the pastor or the priest hire and fire all the employees of the school.
Church officials discipline and control the work of the employees.
The church owns the building in which the school operates.
The employees' salaries are paid directly from the church bank account.
Therefore we believe it is uncontradicted that every key element of the common law definition of employment as incorporated into this statutory scheme is present here.

Nevertheless, the Secretary of Labor and the South Dakota Supreme Court suggest that the word "church" should be confined to mean the physical house of worship rather than the legal entity that owns the building and hires the employees.
As is set forth at some length in the briefs in this case, Congress has consistently provided for a broader definition of "church" in the Internal Revenue Code.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, you normally, though... you wouldn't suggest that normally, when you use the word "church" you think about a church school at the same time?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: No, sir, I think you'd normally--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: In ordinary language you'd talk about those things as different entities.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --Mr. Justice White, I think normally--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: And, legally, you're quite right.
But most people would say, where are you going today?
You'd usually say, I'm going to school, not to church.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --Mr. Justice White, I think it does depend--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Ask anybody where he works, he says, I work at the Baptist school.
He doesn't say I work for a church.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --I think it is correct, Mr. Justice White, that it depends somewhat on the context in which you're speaking.
If someone says on Sunday, I'm going to church, they may perhaps be talking about the building or they may be talking about the worship service.
But Congress used the word
"in the employ of the church. "

And we submit that a church building cannot employ anyone, that in the context of who is the employer, when Congress is setting out a statute about the payment of wages, about the withholding of taxes, that the phrase,
in that context, we submit, had to refer to the definition as petitioners' counsel has stated.
That is also a common definition of "church", which is the body of believers, the legal entity.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Of course, in this case, the employees in question were in the employ of a church, in one case, or an association of churches in the other, were they not?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Stewart, that's correct.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: However defined.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: Well, the Secretary defines the word to mean the building.
And I don't know how you can define the statute with that definition.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Well, you could be employed by a church and work in some other building, I suppose.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: Well, perhaps that's their point.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: Or you could work in a church building and be employed by somebody else.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: We submit that in this context the word "church" must include the legal entity that controls the building and that hires and fires the employees.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: If the building is relevant at all to the legal issues in this case, is it not a fact that in many cases churches and parochial schools are all one structure, a city block, one part of it assigned for worship services, and one part assigned for teaching?
But all in the same building.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: That is exactly--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: The building isn't really very important to the legal issue, is it?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --I don't believe it is.
I think even under the Secretary's interpretation many of these schools since they are in the same building perhaps would be exempt.

But we submit that reliance upon what building the school is in is not what Congress had in mind, and we think that were Congress to find "employer" in this statute as a person who pays wages, then in the same statute, when they use the phrase,
"in the employ of a church. "
we submit they must have meant "church" to mean the legal entity that pays wages, the association, the corporation.
Petitioners in this case are the employing entities within the meaning of that legislative language.
We urge this Court to reject the strained and contorted reading of the statutory language--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Would this also apply to a church hospital?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --Mr. Justice Marshall, I believe that all church hospitals are separately incorporated.
And under our reading of the statute--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, if there possibly would be one that wasn't incorporated?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --If, Mr. Justice Marshall, if the hospital were part of the church itself, were not separately incorporated--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm not talking about the church, I'm talking about St. Isaac's Hospital that's three blocks away from the church but it's owned by the church.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --If it is part of the church, not a separate corporation, then the literal language--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I didn't say... you charged on; I told you the facts.
Is it a part or not a part?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --What I mean to suggest, Mr. Justice, is that if the employees of that hospital are employed by the church entity, as in this case, their salaries paid--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: They are paid by the--

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --from the church account.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: --They are paid by the hospital but the money comes from the church?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: If the hospital has a separate legal identity, in other words, a separate bank account, a separate association, corporation, or structure, then we think that it would not fit within the language of (b)(1)(a).

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Potter Stewart
turn.text: And if the school does, likewise?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Stewart.
We think that a separately incorporated school would in most instances be exempt under (b)(1)(b), but would not fit (b)(1)(a) language, as petitioners do here.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: May I ask just one question?

With regard to the legislative history, in the House report that the Government quotes on page 10 in their brief, it's stated that Section 115(b) also has the effect of requiring the state to pay unemployment compensation on the basis of services performed, for all educational institutions.
Do you think they really didn't mean that?
86 percent, as I understand it, of the schools involved are church-affiliated.

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: That's only true, Mr. Justice Stevens, if you focus on private schools.
And in fact, that language which you just quoted was directly in the context of a lengthy discussion of state and public schools, which was the primary purpose of this statute.
There was no reference in that whole discussion from which the quotation is taken about private schools at all, much less church schools.
In fact, the words 242,000 figure that was referred to earlier is simply a figure in a table, in a report, opposite the phrase, "nonprofit organizations".
There is no discussion of that figure as to what is included within that number, what type of nonprofit organizations, and the record in the Alabama-Nevada case--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Is it not true that normally when one, just as you say, when you work for a school or a church, the same sort of question, when you talk about private schools, private secondary schools, for the most part you are encompassing within that concept a very large number of parochial schools, aren't you?
Do you think that when one just talks about private schools, he intends to refer to nonreligious private schools?
Just in terms of ordinary meaning, as used in everyday parlance?

turn.speaker: allen_r_snyder
turn.label: Mr. Allen R. Snyder
turn.text: --I agree, the great majority of nonprofit private schools are parochial schools but the phrase, nonprofit schools, was not in the language that you quoted, Mr. Justice Stevens.
It simply said, "all educational institutions".
The public schools, of course, are the vast preponderance of those, and were being discussed in that section of the legislative history.
Thank you very much.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well.
Mr. Meierhenry.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, and may it please the Court:

This morning in Watertown, South Dakota, where St. Martin's Lutheran Academy is located... I think it's important to note, because the State believes the second part of petitioners' claims are most appropriate, whether or not it violates the First Amendment... this morning when the children went to school they all went on public school transportation.
Some of those children went to a public school, some of them got off at St. Martin's Academy.
And throughout the day these children who went on different tracks were constantly involved in numerous entanglements, if you would.
They both ate food prepared by private citizens, but the food probably came under Government programs.

Both children in both schools could have had speech and hearing diagnostic services provided for them, which is approved, they most probably used library books furnished by either state or federal funds at St. Martin's Academy--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well, I take it your point is that if they share some of these things, this dilutes the church or religious aspect.
Is that it?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --No, not so much that as to the point made by my colleague that there will be entanglement, should this one small portion of the operation of these parochial schools be subject to some taxation.

In other words, some extraction, of coming under the unemployment compensation laws, whether that will so entangle the state with the operation of these parochial schools as to violate the First Amendment.
My example mainly goes to point out, if it will, to the Court, that this is really not an issue, because this entanglement, by the acceptance of these benefits by church schools, has eliminated that.
And here in this instance... and I argue on behalf of the State for what you will call the people employed by the schools, in other words, the cooks and the janitors.

We recognized by our referee below and in our Supreme Court, that those teachers who are on call, who are part of a religious order or part of their particular religious following, that they are exempted under Section (b) of the exemptions.
So, if they are ministers, they are not covered by unemployment insurance, and we don't make the claim that they are.
What we're worried about, and Congress was worried about it from the beginning of the unemployment law, what about the janitor who is laid off?
What about--

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What about the teachers?
Are they covered?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --Well, I think that some would be and some would not be, depending on a factual determination.

As brought before this Court, those members of the Wisconsin Evangelical Lutheran Church who were called... in other words, their contractual relationship with the school is such that they are considered ministers of the Church, teaching--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: In any event, all of them are in the employ, either of St. Martin Evangelical Lutheran Church, on the one hand, in the one case, or by the Synod in the other case.
Isn't that correct?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --That's correct, Your Honor.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Whether they're cafeteria employees or janitors or lay teachers or whatever?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: That's correct.

I think, though, that if you look at the exemptions and how they occurred, from '70 to 1976 to the present, there would have been absolutely no need for the exemption of ministers and those people who belong to a religious order, for the first exemption.
You would have no need for that for pastors and members of the order.
And the third exemption prior to the change, which we're arguing about, had to do with schools.
And everywhere in their briefs it is always, "church schools".

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: It's always what?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: It's always "church school".
There's always an adjective.
We're talking about private schools, church schools, and public schools.

But we're always talking about schools, and that's what the referee, operating on behalf of the State of South Dakota, found, is it was a school and not a church, and not subject to the first exemption.
Because if that's carried to a logical end, a religious order or a religious society could declare most anything to be in the furtherance of their religion.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: General, that's the point I want.
In declaring these teachers as ministers, does the State consider that they're ministers for income tax purposes?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Well, we don't have an income tax in our state, but I would say this, that--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Are they considered that for federal income taxes?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --No.
The second part of the exemption we recognize.
It says, "ministers".
And we have in this case given to them this exemption as to ministers.
But you don't have to be a minister--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: If that applied, of course that'd apply to this too.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --That's right.
But you don't have to be a minister to be a cook, or a minister to be a janitor.
And that's what the unemployment law is talking about.
Because if they closed down the school, those people who are in the teaching ministry are called to another place.
They're not unemployed.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But you would concede, I gather, that a cook in a church, which everybody agreed was a church, a church building, would be exempt under (1)(a), wouldn't it?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: No, I did not agree under (1)(a).
What I said was, I think that the State can make the determination regardless of what the legal or the paper trail of the legal entity is.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, then, you do not concede that when the statute exempts people in the employ of a church, that it exempts janitors in the employ of the church?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: I did, sir, but the State can make the determination of what is a church purpose, and in this case--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: In my hypothetical case, he sweeps up the church building.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --Well, I guess it's a matter of interpretation of the statute.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And he's employed by the church, and only by the church.
And he knows it and there's no argument otherwise.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Let's take a concrete example.
The Cardinal of the Archidiocese of Washington has a residence and a cook and a housekeeper.
Under (a) is that person exempt, in your view?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Yes.
I would think that we would not argue that those individuals--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We'll resume there at 1 o'clock.
0 [Recess.]
You may continue, Mr. Attorney General.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --Thank you, Mr. Chief Justice.

In response to a question of the Chief Justice, when we broke for lunch, we would point out, and would like the Court to be aware, that these petitioners, and in fact all of the Lutheran schools in the State of South Dakota have submitted themselves to the State and are accredited schools.
But I want to point that we're perhaps a unique state.
We require education in South Dakota.
We do not require attendance at schools.
Therefore, you could educate your children in your own home and you have to be tested to show that you're making academic progress.
But you are not required by compulsory school attendance to attend a school in South Dakota.
However, these petitioners, in both instances, have submitted, and I've lodged with the Court the documents, a copious filing, making them an accredited school in the State of South Dakota.
And that is the only time in our legal jargon that you can be called a school is if you are accredited.
You are either a school and accredited under the State auspices, or you're not.
But you don't have to be a school and you comply with our law of educating your children either by doing it in your home or with a group of others.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How do you suggest that differs from the states which require attendance, so far as the issues here are concerned?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Well, I think it goes to the definition and the exemptions, and I think that we recognize, as the Court does, that this does have to be applied across the land.
And when one is in the employ, as an exception, of a church or convention or association of churches, I think our Supreme Court narrowly interprets that in answer to the Chief Justice's question.
That would probably refer to the cook for the bishop in those things that are obviously only religious.
There is not an educational purpose in being a cook for the bishop.
What there goes on which is probably closer in (b) of 3309, it says:
"Or organization which is operated primarily for religious purposes and which is operated, supervised, controlled, or principally supported by a church or convention or association of churches. "
That's close, but we have to remember, when all these exemptions were entered, number (3) was, in the employ of a school; which has now been eliminated.

And so, in answer to the Chief Justice's question, these people in our opinion, as the documents we lodged show, which were lodged for accreditation purposes, they were filed by the principal of the school, and they were done in the name of the school.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Might they not have been both a school and also an organization which is operated primarily for religious purposes before (3) was repealed?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: They might have been.

But in South Dakota they could not have been a school without meeting accreditation purposes; in other words, making certain statements and complying with certain academic standards, and employing certain types of teachers, and open a certain number of days, which would reduce that being operated primarily for religious purposes.
They were operated primarily as an educational institution.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: All you're saying is that by qualifying as a school they would have come under (3) if it were still in existence.
But that doesn't really go to the (1)(b) question, does it?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Well, I believe it does, because what our appeals referee decided and our Supreme Court decided is that this school, St. Martin's Academy, which is still going on, was not primarily for religious purposes but was primarily for educational purposes, and to be taught with religious overtones, you might say, or in the way that they wish to do it.
But it was primarily for education.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But narrowly, narrowly, the church's embarking in this enterprise is for strictly religious purposes, is it not?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: It could be, but there is a desire wherein I believe--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: They don't want the public school system, or some of the people don't?
They don't want the public school system, they want their system with its heavy emphasis on training in faith and morals?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --That's correct, Mr. Chief Justice.
But then we are told--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Mr. Attorney General, may I ask, I gather that (a), obviously, is limited; (b) can't include a church, because (a) is the exemption for a church.
What is an organization operated primarily for religious purposes, et cetera, if it's neither church nor parochial school?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --I think it would be those instances where it was an institution to train ministers and only--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Seminaries, you mean?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --Seminaries?
It could be.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Why couldn't they say, seminaries?
Everyone knows what a seminary is.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Well, it's not for me to... but I think that it also goes to this extent, Mr. Justice, that certain publishing duties, perhaps certain insurance duties, that would only have something to do with perhaps the churches themselves, not a true free marketplace-type company.

And I think here what they're saying is it's limiting it because they're not going to allow, or Congress is not going to allow for the purposes of covering employees of a church-related organization; if they go into tuna fishing, or lumbering, a lumber company or mining.
So it's going to be a test--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: If they have a diocesan paper, for example, and they have their own print shop, would the printers, do you think, fall under (b) as exempt under (b)?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --I would think not because of the Pilgrim Holiness case which applied the minimum wage requirements of the Fair Labor Act, because in that case, which this Court denied cert; it was a lower court case, but--

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: What if all they printed in that print shop were Bibles?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --I think it would be much closer and it would stand the test, this Court having read--

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice Jr.
turn.text: Well, a diocesan paper is a purely religious paper, isn't it?
Newspaper?

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: At least it is in the Roman Catholic church.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --I'm sorry.
I misunderstood the terms.
That could well be, then, if it were only to print a paper for dissemination to the church.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: My hypothetical was to remove from all doubts the factual question about whether it was or was not a religious document.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: I think in that case that representing a state I would say, yes; if it was organized primarily for religious purposes.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, would an elementary school operated by the church ever be operated primarily for religious purposes in your view?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: I think not, especially in this case where--

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: That's something, if the exemption is available, the authorities would have to decide.
They would have to decide between schools that were operated primarily for religious purposes and the ones that were not.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --I think that that would be a duty of whatever government to decide that.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: General, how come is it impossible for a school to be an "organization"?
Why can't it be an organization?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Well, I think because at the time it was passed in 1970, the paragraph (3) directly approached schools.
It says,
"in the employ of a school which is not an institution of higher education. "
And I think Congress at that time definitely looked at schools, as some of the underlying congressional language reveals, that they were talking about schools--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But is there any other "organization" of a church that would have to comply?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --Yes, I think there probably would be a great number of them.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Like what?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Well, I can't speak and I don't know but I would say that if a church were to have a fleet of school buses that were organized as a corporation, only to bring children to Bible classes or Sunday School classes, that that organization could be organized for the purposes of religion, and if the buses were not used in general commerce.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Well, then the school is the only one that wouldn't be, is the only organization that wouldn't be included.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: I think there could be a great--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: I'm in trouble with school not being an organization.
I think it could be an organization.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --But I think, as you watch the legislative history of 1970, they specifically approach schools, and then in 1978 they specifically said that schools, whether they're public, private, or parochial schools, would not have an exemption.
Because we have to remember that this Act was passed for the benefit of employees, of people who are hired by others, whether they're hired by schools, or whatever, and that these were exemptions.
And I think it was in the intent of Congress, as they have consistently broadened unemployment coverage, was to narrow the scope of exemptions.

And when they looked at the schools, they said, if we just exempt private schools, and we just exempt public schools, then are we not approaching the establishment of religion if we just overlook those religious schools and just those employees will be without protection.

And I think that's a logical argument as to why that each employee, whether he's working in a private school that may be started by environmentalists to promote an environmentalist cause, and still teach, but the primary purpose is education.
And so, when these schools, in our states--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: The primary purpose of a school is education.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --And that's why we believe that--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But they say there's another one; it's religion.
If they wanted just education, they'd send them to public schools.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --Then there would have to be a decision made, as there was in this case, by the appeals referee, that these two institutions were not primarily for educational purposes.
Because these schools, these parochial schools in our state--

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: We can't escape that.
We're going to have to decide that.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --That's right, and I think great weight has to be given to the appeals referee who did determine these issues.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, am I right in reading the statute in this way, that exemption No. (1), both (a) and (b), depends upon the identity of the employer, by contrast with exemption No. (2), which depends entirely upon the identity of the employee?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Yes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: And am I further correct in my understanding that in this case the employer is in the one case a church and in the other an association of churches?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: I guess that is in my mind one of the issues.
I say the employer is the school, it is the school, for the following reason.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Well, the school itself is not an entity, is it?
It's not a corporation?
Isn't the employer who pays the wages the church, in the one case, and an association of churches, i.e., the synod, in the other?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: But the fact remains--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Am I correct in that, factually?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --I think factually that's correct.

The legal effect of that is what I would like to bring to your attention, is the fact that also their description of a church, their description of a church is again not an entity, it's an organization of believers or followers, and what we're talking about here is simply the trail of the dollar that ultimately pays for this.
It does pass through the church.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice Rehnquist
turn.text: But that isn't just their description of the church.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: It's a tracking of (1)(b), isn't it, where it says, an organization which is operated primarily for religious purposes?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Yes, I believe that if they fall under any exception, it's not (a), it's (b), which is an organization--

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Don't they literally fall within (1)(a)?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --I would say not.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Literally?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: No, I would say, not.

Because the individual, as the records show here, the individual is paid by the church, but they're employed by the school with their separate board to oversee... which is within the church, but it's a separate board which hires a principal and eventually runs the school, the entity.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: Maybe we differ as to our understanding of the word "employment" but it seems to me that your employer is the person who pays your salary or wages.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Well, but I think there has to be a determination--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: Doesn't "wages" refer to the employer?

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: "In the employ of".
So it's the identity of the employer, isn't it?

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: "Services performed in the employ of. "

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: "In the employ of".
And the test in (1) is the identify of the employer, by contrast with the test in (2), which is the identity of the employee.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --Well, again, this is an instance, which is the only case before it, but our determination by our Supreme Court was that this instance fell under (b) and that it was not primarily for religious purposes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: So it doesn't fall under (b), because it's not operated primarily for religious purposes.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: That's right; there is no exemption.
But they approached from that standpoint, that it was not primarily for religious purposes, but also--

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: It seems to me that you can't read it the way you're doing it now.
And a church is certainly an organization which is operated primarily for religious purposes, is it not?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: --Yes.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
turn.text: And if you say they're in the employ of a church, they also are in the employ of an organization which is operated primarily for religious purposes.

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: I don't think that necessarily follows.
I don't think that we could deny a church the opportunity... as a wild example... to buy a professional baseball team.

I think they could do that, and I think they could set up their accounting practices in such a way that the money flowed from the church, but that's certainly not an organization, although it's operated by a church and it's supervised by a church and owned, but it's not primarily for religious purposes.

turn.speaker: potter_stewart
turn.label: Justice Stewart
turn.text: But that would be the employer, in your hypothetical case.
And isn't that the statutory test?
The identity of the employer, whatever the nature of the employee's duties, under (1)?

turn.speaker: mark_v_meierhenry
turn.label: Mr. Mark V. Meierhenry
turn.text: Well, I'm not here arguing the intent of the Congress.

turn.speaker: john_paul_stevens
turn.label: Justice John Paul Stevens
